docs.abstract: A M Rosenthal Op-Ed column on 10th anniversary of Tiananmen Square massacre opposes Clinton Administration's policy of 'engagement' with China (M)

headline.main: On My Mind; Meeting At Tiananmen

docs.snippet: Anniversary statement time. For a few days, in America and Europe, politicians will express sorrow at the murder of the young Chinese shot down in Tiananmen Square on June 4, 1989, because they had gathered to cry out for freedom.    Statements will
docs.lead_paragraph: Anniversary statement time. For a few days, in America and Europe, politicians will express sorrow at the murder of the young Chinese shot down in Tiananmen Square on June 4, 1989, because they had gathered to cry out for freedom. Statements will come from two kinds of people. For the sake of the Chinese people, and our national soul, Americans should remember the difference.

docs.abstract: Photo of man standing in front of tanks during demonstrations in Tiananmen Square in 1989
docs.snippet: Photo of man standing in front of tanks during demonstrations in Tiananmen Square in 1989

docs.abstract: Emotional memorials to 1989 Tiananmen massacre are held in many cities around world, but on streets of Beijing there is no public discussion of incident, except for occasional Government announcements defending military action; photo (M)

headline.main: Memories of June 4 Fade, Stunted by Public Silence

docs.snippet: While emotional memorials to the 1989 Tiananmen massacre were held in cities from Hong Kong to New York this week, on the streets of Beijing there was nervous silence.     June 4, 1989, remains China's ultimate skeleton in the closet: the day troops
docs.lead_paragraph: While emotional memorials to the 1989 Tiananmen massacre were held in cities from Hong Kong to New York this week, on the streets of Beijing there was nervous silence. June 4, 1989, remains China's ultimate skeleton in the closet: the day troops ended six weeks of pro-democracy protests in Tiananmen Square with guns and tanks, killing hundreds and injuring thousands.

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton briefly acknowledges 10th anniversary of Tiananmen Square killings and argues, with logic that is meeting increasing skepticism in Congress, that only by pushing ahead on expanding trade with Beijing can US remain 'force for social change in China'; though Congress has often threatened to revoke China's trade status, it has never actually done so, even in months after Tiananmen; some legislators say majority in support of renewal is shrinking (M)

headline.main: Support Shrinks for China's Trade Status

docs.snippet: President Clinton briefly acknowledged the 10th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square killings today and argued, with logic that is meeting increasing skepticism on Capitol Hill, that only by pushing ahead on expanding trade with Beijing can the United
docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton briefly acknowledged the 10th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square killings today and argued, with logic that is meeting increasing skepticism on Capitol Hill, that only by pushing ahead on expanding trade with Beijing can the United States remain ''a force for social change in China.'' Though members of Congress were not formally in Washington to receive Mr. Clinton's annual notification that he was renewing ''normal trade relations'' with China, they said they expected Mr. Clinton would once again prevail. Though Congress has often threatened to revoke China's trade status, it has never actually done so, even in the months after Tiananmen.

docs.abstract: Bao Tong, highest Chinese Government official jailed for sympathizing with 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations, has been talking publicly about Tiananmen Square killings since his 1998 release and is stepping up efforts as 10th anniversary of crackdown nears; calls killings national tragedy and political error, interview; photo (M)

headline.main: Former Insider Still Hopes Leaders Will Rethink the 1989 Tiananmen Crackdown

docs.snippet: Since last year, Bao Tong, a former senior Communist Party official, has been prodding and exhorting China's leaders to rethink their verdict on June 4, 1989, when soldiers used guns to quash a massive pro-democracy protest, killing hundreds in and a
docs.lead_paragraph: Since last year, Bao Tong, a former senior Communist Party official, has been prodding and exhorting China's leaders to rethink their verdict on June 4, 1989, when soldiers used guns to quash a massive pro-democracy protest, killing hundreds in and around Tiananmen Square. Mr. Bao, the highest Government official jailed after the crackdown, spent seven years in prison, followed by two years of house arrest, for sympathizing with the protesters. He was released in May 1998 and quickly started talking publicly from time to time about the incident.

docs.abstract: United Nations panel refuses to grant nongovernmental organization status to Human Rights in China, New York-based human rights organization that is campaigning to bring criminal charges against Chinese leaders responsible for massacre around Tiananmen Square in 1989; United States, France and Ireland are only members of 19-nation UN Committee on Nongovernmental Organizations to vote in favor of giving group official status; official status would allow group to attend UN meetings and present evidence to UN panels; China is among 13 countries on panel that opposed official status for group (M)

headline.main: U.N. Denies Status to Rights Group Critical of '89 Massacre in China

docs.snippet: Ten years to the day after the massacre around Tiananmen Square, special United Nations status has been denied to a New York-based human rights organization that has been helping victims' families in a campaign to bring criminal charges against Chine
docs.lead_paragraph: Ten years to the day after the massacre around Tiananmen Square, special United Nations status has been denied to a New York-based human rights organization that has been helping victims' families in a campaign to bring criminal charges against Chinese leaders responsible for the 1989 killings. After China spoke against the measure, the United Nations Committee on Nongovernmental Organizations refused, by a vote of 13 to 3, to grant nongovernmental organization status to Human Rights in China. This week, the group announced that it helped the families file a petition with the Government in Beijing last month seeking a criminal investigation into the 1989 military crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators. Hundreds of civilians are believed to have been killed.

docs.abstract: Many people in Beijing express disappointment after China loses to US, 5-4, on penalty kicks in Women's World final; photo (M)

headline.main: The View From China: 'So Close, So Close'

docs.snippet: Those fateful penalty kicks.     They were played and replayed over and over on television all over China today, stinging each time like pinpricks in the consciousness of a nation whose hope was deflated when Brandi Chastain made the last of the pena
docs.lead_paragraph: Those fateful penalty kicks. They were played and replayed over and over on television all over China today, stinging each time like pinpricks in the consciousness of a nation whose hope was deflated when Brandi Chastain made the last of the penalty kicks to give the United States a victory over China in the Women's World Cup final.

docs.abstract: Chinese Pres Jiang Zemin reportedly plans nationwide ban on Buddhist Law, amorphous but fast-growing spiritual movement; arrests of over 100 prominent members in 14 cities has spurred protests by thousands of followers in Beijing and other cities; police reportedly quickly herd into buses and take away members who mass in front of Communist Party compound, Beijing; Li Hongzhi, sect leader, who is now based in United States, uses Internet to communicate with followers; photos (M)

headline.main: China Said to Prepare Ban on Sect; Protests Go On

docs.snippet: Ratcheting up its campaign against an amorphous but fast-growing spiritual movement, the Chinese Government is expected to announce today a nationwide ban against the movement, Buddhist Law, according to reports in three Hong Kong newspapers.    The
docs.lead_paragraph: Ratcheting up its campaign against an amorphous but fast-growing spiritual movement, the Chinese Government is expected to announce today a nationwide ban against the movement, Buddhist Law, according to reports in three Hong Kong newspapers. The papers said President Jiang Zemin had decided to impose the ban at an emergency meeting of the Politburo on Monday. The independent daily Sing Tao quoted the Government directive as saying the group had ''engaged in superstition and disrupted public order, thereby damaging social stability.''

docs.abstract: Elisabeth Rosenthal travel article on Dong Yue Temple, Taoist temple in Beijing, China, which has been restored and reopened after nearly century of neglect; photos; map (M)

headline.main: In a Beijing Temple, Deities Reawaken

docs.snippet: ALONG a Beijing street lined with shopping malls and choked with traffic, there is a simple gate painted red that had been closed to visitors for many years. The only hint of what lay within were the gnarled tops of ancient trees -- in this city, a r
docs.lead_paragraph: ALONG a Beijing street lined with shopping malls and choked with traffic, there is a simple gate painted red that had been closed to visitors for many years. The only hint of what lay within were the gnarled tops of ancient trees -- in this city, a rare and enticing commodity. In March, the gate finally opened to reveal the exquisitely restored Dong Yue Temple, during its long heyday the largest and most important Taoist temple in northern China.

docs.abstract: Taiwanese rock-and-roll singer Ah-Mei dazzles Beijing with animated persona and sexual suggestiveness, drawing over 45,000 screaming fans to city's biggest stadium amid China-Taiwan political crisis; Chinese seem to take for granted Taiwan culture that has infused mainland China over last 15 years; photos (M)

headline.main: Beijing Journal; What Crisis? A Taiwan Temptress Seduces China

docs.snippet: China is crazy about Ah-Mei. And she rocked Beijing tonight, sending a stadium full of fans into a tizzy of screeching adulation.     Ah-Mei can sing all right, and her  dancing does dazzle, oh yeah. But it is Ah-Mei's sexy charm and suggestive stage
docs.lead_paragraph: China is crazy about Ah-Mei. And she rocked Beijing tonight, sending a stadium full of fans into a tizzy of screeching adulation. Ah-Mei can sing all right, and her dancing does dazzle, oh yeah. But it is Ah-Mei's sexy charm and suggestive stage work that seem to have suddenly catapulted her to the No. 1 slot in rock-and-roll popularity in China.
